article: More than thirty years ago, I drove a cab for a living. I met people whose lives amazed me, made me _ and weep. But none touched me more than a woman I _ up late one August night. was responding to a call in a quiet part of town. When I arrived at 2:30 am, the building was _ except for a single light in a ground floor window. I walked to the door and _ . The door opened. A small woman in her 80s _ before me. By her side was a small suitcase. I took the suitcase to the _ , and then returned to help the woman. She took my arm and we walked _ toward the cab. She kept _ me for my kindness. When we got in the cab, she gave me a(n) _ and asked, "Can you drive through downtown?"  For the next two hours, we drove _ the city. She showed me the building where she had _ worked as an elevator operator. We drove through the neighborhood where she and her husband had lived _ they were newlyweds. She _ me pull up in front of a house that had once been a ballroom where she had gone _ as a girl. Sometimes she'd ask me to slow in front of a particular building and would sit _ into the darkness, saying nothing.   As the day _ , we got to the address she had given me. It was a hospice . Two orderlies came out to the cab as _ as we pulled up. They must have been _ her. I took the small suitcase to the door. "You gave an old woman a little moment of _ ,"she said. "Thank you." I squeezed her hand, then walked into the dim morning light. Behind me, a door shut. It was the sound of the _ of a life. I didn't pick up any more passengers that shift. I drove aimlessly, lost in thought.
